title: How to Spot Illness in Hamsters

steps.title: Look for a wet tail covered in feces.
steps.content: Look for a wet tail covered in feces. Wet tail is a gastrointestinal disease caused by a bacterial infection. The biggest telltale sign is when the fur around its tail is soaked in urine or feces. You may also see your hamster urinating or defecating and not moving away from it. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Search for diarrhea in the cage.
steps.content: Search for diarrhea in the cage. A sick hamster’s wet bottom is the result of diarrhea, so apart from spotting it on your hamster’s body, look for diarrhea elsewhere in the cage. Using a gloved finger, sift through its usual bathroom area as well as the rest of the bedding throughout the cage. [2] X Research source Diarrhea by itself is not indicative of wet tail. It usually means your hamster has eaten too many fruits and vegetables. Small animals with diarrhea can get dehydrated really quickly, so it's important to take them to the vet right away. [3] X Research source Star of Texas Veterinary Hospital. Veterinarians.

steps.title: Watch for a decreased appetite.
steps.content: Watch for a decreased appetite. Observe your hamster’s food bowl and see if it’s staying fuller than normal. Because hamsters tend to hoard food, check the bedding throughout the cage for lots of rotten food that it hid but didn't eat. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Note any aggressive behavior.
steps.content: Note any aggressive behavior. Sick hamsters feel more vulnerable, so they may lash out at their owners or at other hamsters. [5] X Research source Star of Texas Veterinary Hospital. Veterinarians. If your hamster isn't normally aggressive and it bites you, then this could be a sign that it's ill. Do not continue to handle it if you notice increased signs of aggression. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Watch for increased sleep.
steps.content: Watch for increased sleep. Hamsters usually sleep a lot during the day, so you may need to stay up late to observe its nighttime routine. If it seems like it's waking infrequently both during the day and at night, and its energy level is lower than normal while awake, your hamster may be ill. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Call your veterinarian as soon as possible.
steps.content: Call your veterinarian as soon as possible. Wet tail is one of the most serious and fast-acting diseases your hamster can contract. Don't hesitate to call your vet, even if you're unsure. Calling within 24 hours of spotting these symptoms will give your hamster the best shot at recovery. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Look for discharge from its nose or eyes.
steps.content: Look for discharge from its nose or eyes. Your hamster shouldn’t normally have nasal discharge, so take note of a runny nose and goopy or wet eyes. Occasional sneezing is normal, but if you’re seeing these symptoms accompanied by lots of sneezing, then your hamster is probably sick. [9] X Research source Your hamster may just have a simple cold, but this can potentially turn into pneumonia, so take these signs seriously and observe your hamster for any worsening symptoms over the next 24 to 48 hours.

steps.title: Listen for labored breathing.
steps.content: Listen for labored breathing. If your hamster is having trouble breathing or it sounds like it's wheezing, it may have a respiratory infection. [10] X Research source Star of Texas Veterinary Hospital. Veterinarians. Labored breathing may be typical after exercise though, so pay special attention to any wheezing while your hamster is resting.

steps.title: Watch for any shivering.
steps.content: Watch for any shivering. If your hamster is shivering and also has a runny nose, it likely has an infection in its lungs. Call your veterinarian to ask what they recommend, and if possible, try to warm your home or the room it's in by turning up the thermostat or using a space heater. Never place anything hot (such as a space heater) right next to the cage. Temperatures above 75 °F (24 °C) can be unhealthy for your hamster.

steps.title: Note any abnormal lethargy.
steps.content: Note any abnormal lethargy. Observe your hamster during times when it's normally active, which should be around the time you feed it during the day, or for several hours at night. If it's not running in its wheel at night, this could be a sign that it's not feeling well.

steps.title: Look for flaky or red skin.
steps.content: Look for flaky or red skin. When you handle your hamster each day, briefly run your fingertips through its coat to view the skin underneath. Flaky, dry, or red skin could be the result of an allergy to new bedding, but it could also mean your hamster has mites or ringworm. [11] X Research source Remove anything new you’ve added to the cage recently, and clean and disinfect everything else. If your hamster’s skin issues continue, you can probably rule out an allergy. Avoid using wood chips as your hamster’s bedding, since these are likely to cause allergic reactions. Stick to paper bedding and shavings instead. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Check inside swollen cheeks for food.
steps.content: Check inside swollen cheeks for food. Hamsters often shove food into their cheeks until they balloon out from their face. If your hamster’s cheeks look like this all the time, try to get a look inside its mouth to see if there’s any food inside. If not, your hamster probably has an abscess in their cheek, and it will need to be drained by your veterinarian. [13] X Research source Abscesses are caused by something cutting the inside of your hamster’s cheek, so be sure not to offer any snacks or treats that have jagged or sharp edges.

steps.title: Look for a matted coat and excessive scratching.
steps.content: Look for a matted coat and excessive scratching. If your hamster’s normally soft fur is suddenly matted or missing in spots, that could be a sign of a skin problem. See if it’s accompanied by lots of scratching, which could mean your hamster has mites. Hair loss by itself could simply be the result of abrasive bedding, rubbing against the wheel, or a leaky water bottle. It's also a sign of kidney problems in older hamsters.

steps.title: Watch for any blood on its body or in its cage.
steps.content: Watch for any blood on its body or in its cage. It may be tough to see issues on your hamster’s skin, but if there’s something serious, like an open sore, you’ll likely see blood somewhere on its coat. You may also see it somewhere else in the cage, like in the bedding where it sleeps. [14] X Research source When you clean your hamster’s cage each week, look for any abnormalities or changes in the bedding you’re discarding.

steps.title: Check for lumps on your hamster's body.
steps.content: Check for lumps on your hamster's body. Lumps can be a sign of abscesses, cysts, or tumors. [15] X Research source Star of Texas Veterinary Hospital. Veterinarians. To check for lumps, gently feel around your hamster's body with your hands. If you notice a lump, take your hamster to the vet as soon as possible.

steps.title: Examine your hamster's incisor teeth.
steps.content: Examine your hamster's incisor teeth. If your hamster's incisor teeth look overgrown, it could be a sign that it's not eating properly. Overgrown incisor teeth can lead to complications, like difficulty eating. If your hamster's teeth look overgrown, take it to the vet to have it examined.
